prompt.p: A 70-year-old man presents with confusion over the last 48 hours. On examination he has a temperature of 35.5°C, heart rate of 55 beats/min, respiratory rate of 9 breaths/min, and a blood pressure of 150/80 mmHg. On examination, he has a third heart sound, bi-basal crackles and bilateral pitting ankle oedema. His capillary blood glucose is 2.5 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.8 mmol/L) and blood tests show hyponatraemia.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option B is Correct. Hypothermia, hypoventilation, bradycardia, heart failure and hypoglycaemia indicate severe hypothyroidism.
Option A is Incorrect. Clinical features of alcohol withdrawal syndrome include tachycardia, hypertension, confusion, hallucinations and seizures.
Option C is Incorrect. Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminaemia and oedema.
Option D is Incorrect. Pseudodementia is a symptom of depression with apparent reversible cognitive impairment. It would not be associated with the systemic features present in this patient.

Option E is Incorrect. Transient ischaemic attack causes sudden focal loss of CNs function due to temporary cerebral artery occlusion. Symptoms include hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, dysphasia, amaurosis fugax, vertigo, diplopia and homonymous hemianopia.
